NOTES | 6. All concrete supplied to the site shall be from concrete supplier(s) accredited to code I.S. EN 206:2013/NA:2015. The Main Contractor shall provide evidence of this accreditation to the Engineer at least five working days prior to any concrete delivery. Should the Main Contractor elect to change concrete supplier during the contract, fresh certification of accreditation will be required. The Main Contractor shall obtain certification from the supplier, in accordance with I.S. EN 206:2013/NA:2015, that all concrete supplied meets the requirements of the specification. See also separate note re site diary. Exposure classes quoted are to I.S. EN 206:2013/NA:2015; where more than one exposure class is noted, the concrete supplied is required to at least meet the requirements of all classes noted. PILING | Contractor shall ensure that any movements of the ground and adjacent buildings, and any vibrations induced by the piling installation are kept within the following specified limits: | 1). Ground movements (vertical & horizontal) resulting from piling works shall be less than 5mm at any location.
PILING | 2). Vertical and horizontal movements of adjacent buildings resulting from piling shall be less than 3mm
PILING | 3). Vibration levels shall be less than 3mm/sec ppv (over frequency range 8-30Hz); and 8mm/sec ppv (over frequency range 30-100hz), Measured at foundation level of adjacent buildings.
PILING | The Contractor shall install and monitor instrumentation and monitoring stations to ensure that the piling works are carried out at the specified frequency.

PILING | Notes:- | Refer to Engineers Drawing nr 1321_101B and Main Household Specific Piling Notes 1. to 24. | 1. Raft to be supported on 60 tonne Working Load Piles. Piles to be Contractor Designed Elements, subject to Engineer's approval of Contractor submitted design. Tendering Contractor should note that Site Investigation Report is included in tender documents. The Contractor must make their own evaluation of this and allow for this in their tender and their proposed pile design. Piles to be precast driven. Piling specialists will be aware that the risk of requiring additional piles for breakages and other reasons with driven piles will be greater than for bored or CFA piles. Contractor's reading of Site Investigation, and their design for providing piles of the required capacity for the conditions presented, are at the Contractor's risk. Contractors to allow, in their tenders, for this risk and for the risk of ground conditions varying between the locations investigated and reported in the Site Investigation Report.

PILING | 2. Where obstructions or breakages require additional piles, the Contractor shall be deemed to have allowed for these in his tender. The replacement or additional pile may need to be provided out of the position specified on the Piling layout drawing. Where such out of position piles are required, the Contractor should inform the engineer of the difficulty and the options, giving the engineer not less than one full working day to advise the contractor of the preferred new position. The preferred new position should be on the beam thickenings. If for any reason the engineer is unable to provide the preferred alternative position to the Contractor within 24 hours of being requested, the Contractor shall follow this rule of moving along the beam thickenings. Where out of position piles as described here are required, there may be some additional concrete and/or reinforcement required . The Contractor will be deemed to have allowed for this in his tender.

PILING | 3. Contractor to provide Engineer with electronic AutoCAD as-constructed pile layout drawings indicating dimensions X and Y to centre of pile from specified position. This drawing is required by Engineer not less than four days before he can release reinforcing schedules for piled raft. Contractor is to note this in preparing his programme.

PILING | 4. Contractor to allow for piles to be 10m long, but tendering Contractors must make their own assessment of this, based upon their own site investigation report. The Risk in that interpretation passes to the Contractor.

PILING | 5. Notwithstanding the Contractor's pile design and installation of the piles shall, at a minimum, meet the requirements of the separate typed specifications. In particular, lack of verticality of installed piles shall not exceed 1 in 75. Contractor shall expose 300mm of all piles so that this may be checked on site. Where the engineer is concerned regarding the verticality, he may request that a further 300mm is exposed to allow for a more accurate measurement. The engineer's determination on verticality shall be considered final.

PILING | 6. Notwithstanding the contractor's pile design, all piles shall have a minimum of 4 no. B16 bars anchored not less than 2m below the cut-down pile down into the pile and projecting not less than 500mm up into the RC Raft, to allow for a full monolithic engagement between the pile and the raft.

PILING | 7. Piling contractor shall check and satisfy himself with the verticality of all piles before leaving site. The Client shall not be liable for any cost or delay in the Contractor having to get a piling specialist to return to site to install any additional piles to replace piles found not to meet the specifications.
PILING | 8. See Piling Layout for location of piles. Piles to be centred on grids, or offset as shown.
PILING | 9. The proposed building is located within the campus of an active healthcare site, with a myriad of underground services.

PILING | 10. A survey of underground services forms part of the tender documents. This may not have necessarily identified all underground services. The contractor is required to thoroughly survey the proposed site for buried services before any works commence. The underside of the main raft edge beam thickening at pile locations is at a certain distance below existing ground level. It is recommended that all pile locations be carefully excavated to at least this level before piling commences. Arisings may be used to backfill up to level of proposed tops of piles, provided that this material can be compacted to serve as shuttering for the pile head.

PILING | 11. CCTV Survey of Existing Drainage and Structural Condition Survey of adjacent buildings to be carried out prior to any excavation or piling work. Vibration monitor to be installed and monitored in all neighbouring buildings while piles are installed.

PILING | 12. Main Contractors to agree details of piling platform requirements with their piling subcontractors. Attention is drawn to site investigation findings. Main Contractors will be deemed to have allowed for any piling platform or mat requirements. Minimum of 150mm clean clause 808 type stone to be provided below radon barrier, to allow for easy ventilation and to form up banks for piled RC raft.

PILING | 13. Pile design calculations to be submitted to the consulting engineer's office not less than three weeks before it is proposed to commence piling. See also separate note on concrete suppliers.

PILING | 14. Should obstructions be found, the preference would be to "drift" the pile in the line of the raft beams to be formed over. Locations of obstructions and drifting options to be reported from site to consulting engineer's office for directions on such drifting.

PILING | 15. Main Contractors to agree details of piling platform requirements with their piling subcontractors will be deemed to have allowed for any piling platform or mat requirements. Minimum of 150mm clean clause 808 type stone
PILING | 16. Daily piling logs are to be provided at the end of each day's piling to the consulting engineer.

PILING | 17. All piles are to be integrity tested; not less than 10% of the total number of piles, and not less than four piles per testing visit, to be selected at random by the consulting engineer's office, are to be dynamically load tested. If any of the 30% do not meet the standard, all remaining piles are to be dynamically load tested. Any defective piles are to be replaced, and integrity and dynamically load tested.

PILING | 18. Contractor to provide as-constructed survey of the piles on completion of piling, supplying the information to the consulting engineer's office in AutoCAD format, to allow reinforcing schedule to be confirmed. Contractors to note that the ground/raft foundation schedule will not be issued for construction until at least 5 working days after receipt of the full as-constructed pile survey.

PILING | 19. Care to be taken in dressing down piles to required level. Reinforcement is to be allowed to project up to within 75mm of top of raft. Concrete is to be carefully trimmed below this level, to project minimum 100mm into 1050mm local raft thickenings over piles 500mm below top of raft.

PILING | 20. Should pile trimming works cut reinforcing so that pile reinforcing does not have the specified anchorage into the raft, the contractor will be required, at his own expense, to carefully trim the pile 650mm further down; place additional reinforcing with the required lap of 40 diameter; and re-form the pile up to the underside of raft level with new C35/40 concrete up to the require level

PILING | 21. All piling works and radon protection measures to be carried out and certified by approved specialists. Specialists to be identified in tender documents. See Quantity Surveyor's documents for PI insurance and warranty requirements. Full method statements will be required from these specialists prior to commencement of any works on site. The design team reserve the right to reject, on the Client's behalf, any specialist proposed by the contractor if they have any concerns about any aspects of the specialists proposals or method statements.
PILING | 22. All shuttering, including stone banks, shall be sufficiently stable and robust to allow for good compaction of the concrete.

PILING | 23. Piled suspended raft should not be loaded up with blocks until at least ten days after the concrete has been placed. Care should be taken to avoid stacking bales of blocks at the centre of panels away from the supporting beams and piles.
PILING | 24. Given the sites the close proximity to patients residential living quarters, piling is not to be carried out before 9am or after 6pm.

PILING | For each pile; setting up over each pile location (piling mat measured separately)

PILING | Concrete driven piles shall be in accordance with the Concrete Specification
contained within. All Concrete design and works will be the responsibility of the Contractor. The Contractor is to ensure that he has a suitable concrete source with a guaranteed continuity of supply. The concrete shall have a high workability (75-125 mm slump) to suit the piling method employed. The concrete workability shall be determined using slump or flow table in accordance with I.S. EN 12350-2:2009. The slump or flow shall be measured at the time of discharge into the pile boring and shall be in accordance with the above limits or Table 3.1 of the ICE specification. The aggregates used to make the piles shall be free from the presence of pyrite or marcasite. The Contractor shall allow for the testing of the materials on or offsite prior to use. NOTES | 1. Not withstanding that this Bill of Quantities is measured in accordance with the Agreed Rules of Measurement, the tenderer should note the following works measured are not in accordance with ARM. The Air Tightness specialised design packages are priced in accordance with the Works Requirements and the relevant co-ordination is to include for all works there in contained.

NOTES | 2. Ensuring the airtight quality of the buildings is a key element of the low energy strategy applied in the design of this building. Care has been taken by the designers in specifying the materials and systems and in providing construction details that are capable of achieving the specified level of air permeability.
NOTES | 3. The contractor shall be responsible for ensuring that the building complies with the specified level of air permeability.
NOTES | 4. When tested the building shall achieve an air permeability of 3m3/hr/m2 @50 Pa building pressure or less.
NOTES | 5. Refer to Section A33 of Architects Specification for this Section

NOTES | The contractor shall include the cost of carrying out the following works if not included elsewhere in this Pricing Document. | The main elements of the building construction providing protection against air infiltration (the seal boundary) are typically: | 1. U/s of  WPB ply to flat roof
NOTES | 2. U/s of precast slab roof
NOTES | 3. Taped Insulation to external face of blockwork/concrete walls
NOTES | 4. Tapes/seals at the glazing system
NOTES | 5. Radon membrane
NOTES | 6. Ventilation dampers
NOTES | 7. Seals/grommits to all penetrations through the external wall/floor roof/envelope.
NOTES | 8. Membranes within cavities and seals to steel structures.

NOTES | The sealing of the construction junctions between these elements is a critical aspect of the airtight design. It is essential that the air seal boundary is continuous and is not breached in any location. All service penetrations which cross the line of the air seal boundary also must be comprehensively sealed to maintain continuity of the airtight barrier, with proprietary products as per the general specification.
NOTES | Quality Management | Effective and thorough quality management is essential if the specified level of air permeability is to be achieved.

NOTES | If the integrity of the air seal boundary is broken then it must be repaired. Particular care must be taken when constructing joints and junctions in the building envelope to ensure continuity of the air seal boundary. Repairs using unsuitable tape, Rockwool and expanding foam are not acceptable.

NOTES | In addition to the continuity of the air seal boundary, care must be exercised at all envelope penetrations for windows, doors, rooflights, services, cables etc applying appropriate sealing and draught barriers and sealing junctions between the air seal boundary and these elements.

NOTES | For the low air permeability strategy to be successful it is vital that all site workers are aware of the importance of maintaining the integrity of the air seal boundary.  All subcontractors are to be briefed on the strategy and encouraged to report damage of the air seal boundary on a ''no fault'' basis.

NOTES | The main contractor shall take overall responsibility for co-ordination of and maintaining continuity of the air seal boundary. One member of the contractor's site team is to be nominated as the 'air leakage officer', whose role shall include the following; | Develop the project air leakage prevention plan
NOTES | Identify all significant potential sources of air leakage and the methods to be used to minimise leakage
NOTES | Ensure that all tapes and sealants used to minimise air leakage are fit for purpose and offer a long term protection to air leakage over the buildings lifetime
NOTES | Ensure that all equipment and components procured offer the required standard of air leakage
NOTES | Ensure that all sub contractors understand the importance of minimising air leakage in this building and take appropriate measures to minimise it
NOTES | Undertake regular inspections of the building as it is constructed to ensure that air leakage paths are minimised
NOTES | Ensure that no elements of the construction are concealed without their air leakage integrity being considered and inspected
NOTES | Program the air test and prepare the building for its test
NOTES | Supervise the test procedure, including ensuring that all required temporary seals are applied to allow the test to take place
NOTES | Identify sources of leakage during the test procedure and their potential resolution in the event that the target air tightness is not achieved

NOTES | The main contractor shall ensure coordination of work between different work packages/ specialist sub-contractors in defining responsibility for sealing at junctions between different construction elements.
NOTES | Areas critical in maintaining the air seal boundary include (but are not limited to): | Monitoring and maintaining levels of construction quality
NOTES | Roof/ wall junctions
NOTES | Ground floor/ wall junction
NOTES | Changes in roof section
NOTES | Windows, doors and rooflights
NOTES | Service penetrations
NOTES | All materials systems junctions

NOTES | Airtightness Specialist | The contractor shall employ a recognised specialist approved by the Employer's Representative to carry out an airtightness test at a point in the construction programme when all elements of the external envelope/ air seal boundary are complete including all services penetrations.

NOTES | The specialist must have had previous experience in the testing of buildings to IS EN 13829 2001 that have achieved the target set out below or improved on it, in at least one building of a similar size and complexity.

NOTES | The specialist shall provide a rig capable of testing the entire building as a single element.  If the air test results show that the rig was unable to maintain a pressure of 50Pa at the required test result, the test will be deemed non-compliant
NOTES | The air test shall be carried out as detailed within the following standards: | IS EN 13829:2001 "Determination of air permeability in buildings - fan pressurisation method"
NOTES | CIBSE TM23:2000 "Testing buildings for air leakage"
NOTES | ATTMA TS1 July 2007 "Measuring air permeability of building envelopes"
NOTES | All instruments and equipment used must comply with the accuracy and tolerance requirements set down by these standards.

NOTES | The air test specialist must be accredited through INAB or UKAS to carry out air tightness testing of buildings in accordance with ISO 17025 - proof of this accreditation must be issued by the contractor to the ER and approved in writing, prior to appointment.
NOTES | The contractor shall also include for a minimum of 2 no site inspection from the accredited testing specialists during the course of construction.

NOTES | Briefing Meeting | Upon approval and appointment of the air testing specialist by the contractor, and at an appropriate time in the building programme, the specialist shall hold a briefing meeting with the contractors staff and the design team. Prior to this meeting, the contractor shall identify any points in the building that have a high risk of air leakage and shall detail the proposed sealing method with the air test specialist.
NOTES | The air test specialist shall also use this opportunity to detail the testing procedure and work required in preparation for the test.

NOTES | Preliminary Smoke Test | Once the glazing is installed, the contractor shall employ the air test specialist to carry out a smoke test on 3 no. typical rooms in the building, of differing sizes, scales and complexities, in order to identify any potential weaknesses in the installation that can be rectified before the full test is carried out.
NOTES | Note that an amount of temporary sealing will be required to prevent smoke escaping internally during the testing of this room.
NOTES | The contractor shall contact the local fire department in advance of the test and inform them that the smoke test may take place in order to prevent false alarms.

NOTES | Test Preparation | The contractor shall include all attendances associated with the airtightness testing including building preparation which shall typically include: | (a) all external windows, trickle vents, smoke vents and doors must be closed (but not sealed)
NOTES | (b) all internal doors must be wedged open
NOTES | (c) all drainage traps must be filled with water. If traps have not been fitted then drainage pipes must be sealed with tape

NOTES | (d) all mechanical ventilation systems must be shut down and intake/ exhaust louvers sealed with tape/ polythene sheeting / compriband. This is most effectively achieved by sealing the intake and exhaust louvers for each fan or system
NOTES | (e) any combustion appliances within the airtight building envelope should be turned off and their flues sealed
NOTES | (f) the ground floor internal and external area within 5m of the fan equipment/ doorway must be clean and clear of all loose material
NOTES | (g) the contractor must ensure that no external doors/ windows/ trickle vents are opened for the duration of the test
NOTES | (h) some temporary minor carpentry works may be required to the doorway in which the fan equipment is mounted
NOTES | (j) notices must be posted at all entry and exit points to the building; ''AIRTIGHTNESS TEST IN PROGRESS DO NOT OPEN''.
NOTES | (k) remove suspended floor and ceiling tiles (where applicable) around the perimeter of the building
NOTES | (l) contractor to advise the employers representative of the proposed test date one month prior to the test date, weekend days may not be acceptable
NOTES | (m) Air test may only be carried out during appropriate weather conditions
NOTES | (n) contractor to obtain a list of test condition requirements from the air leakage test specialist four weeks prior to carrying out the air test
NOTES | (o) The building shall be brought up to normal working temperature 6 hours before the test is due to take place and maintained at the working temperature during the air and thermograph tests
NOTES | Note that no additional taping or sealing of any building component must be undertaken without prior agreement from the client's representative.

NOTES | No less than three weeks before the test is due to commence, the contractor shall measure the surface area that is proposed for use in the test and send the calculation to the clients representative for agreement.

NOTES | The Test | The building shall achieve an air leakage level of 3m3/h/m2 at a test pressure of 50Pa, or less. (Where the area used is the true internal exposed area of the walls, roof, window, and ground floor surfaces).
NOTES | The air test shall be carried out as detailed within the following standards: | IS EN 13829:2001 "Determination of air permeability in buildings - fan pressurisation method"
NOTES | CIBSE TM23:2000 "Testing buildings for air leakage"
NOTES | ATTMA TS1 July 2007 "Measuring air permeability of building envelopes"
NOTES | All instruments and equipment used must comply with the accuracy and tolerance requirements set down by these standards.
NOTES | The test must be witnessed by the Employers Representative. The contractor shall give sufficient notice to enable this to happen.

NOTES | The air testing specialist must produce a full detailed report of the air test on completion, identifying the area used for the test, the result achieved, and confirmation of any deviations from the standard test procedure

NOTES | In the event the test is failed the contractor shall carry out a full building smoke test to identify sources of leakage. The smoke test shall be carried out by filling the building with a smoke type that is harmless to the building and its systems and leave no residues within the building. During this test the contractor shall make a detailed list of all leakage points.
NOTES | The contractor shall promptly carry out all necessary remedial works and, cover all costs of further air and smoke tests required to prove compliance with the test standard.
NOTES | The contractor shall remove all building elements required to correctly seal the building and re-instate them to allow the further testing of the building until compliance is achieved.

NOTES | Thermographic Survey | The contractor shall employ a recognised specialist to carry out a thermographic survey of the completed building to prove continuity of insulation within all parts of the building fabric.
NOTES | The survey shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements and recommendations of TN 9/2002 'Thermal Imaging of Buildings'.
NOTES | The survey shall be carried out by a Level III certified thermographer.

NOTES | In the event that the specified continuity of thermal insulation is not achieved the contractor shall open up the works and make good the deficiency.  A further thermographic survey of the relevant areas is to be carried out to complete the demonstration of compliance with the specification.
NOTES | Any opening up or remedial works required are to be carried out at the contractors' expense until the specified performance is achieved.
